story: Huge BBC shake-up expected with very dferent role planned for Laura KuenssbergSpeculation is re that Laura Kuenssberg will step down as the BBC News political editor, freeing up the role for US Editor Jon Sopel, who has announced histo the UKLaura Kuenssberg is said to be in talks to become a presenter on Radio s Today programme Image: BBCByNicola Methven:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA BBC News shake-up looks on the cards after US Editor Jon Sopel announced he is ing to the UK after seven years. Speculation is re Laura Kuenssberg is in talks to become a presenter on Radio ’s Today programme after six years as BBC Political Editor, potentially freeing up the job for Sopel.He was linked to the role in  when it went to Kuenssberg, , who became the first woman in the role. She has covered two general elections, the Brexit referendum and the pandemic.Sopel, , is tipped to be replaced in Washington DC by Sarah Smith, , the current BBC Scotland editor, meaning that position would become vacant.The role of leading the coverage of Scotland is seen as important following criticism from the SNP government. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Announcing his decision toto the UK this week, Sopel tweeted: “After + fab years in DC,  books,  presidentsit’s time toto the UK and BBC mothership. “Planning a long break. New book, maybe – but most of all for us to get to Australia to meet our first grandchild, Eliza.” BBC political editors are often appointed long before general elections to give them time to bed in. Today already has five presenters, but some may change roles. One insider said: “Jon’s decision toto the UK is being seen as a catalyst for a chain of events because he’s a big hitter and needs a big role.  “Any move by Laura would have to be her decision – she’s done a brilliant job as political editor, but it’s not one that people want to do forever. “Nothing is going to happen in the very short term but next year is likely to bring some changes.” Another potential vacancy is main anchor of BBC News at Ten after Huw Edwards suggested he might be ready to quit. Speaking as he turned  this summer, Huw said he fancied “something dferent”. He explained: “The nightly news business, after  years, that can be taxing – even though I still enjoy the job. But I don’t think I’ll be doing that for long.  “In the first place, I think it’s fair for the viewers to get a change. Secondly, I have co-workers who are very talented. It’s time to give them a chance too.” One BBC broadcaster not thought to be going anywhere is Andrew Marr, who has landed a fresh contract to front his Sunday morning politics show. A BBC spokesman said: “The North America editor role is currently being advertised internally and the role will go through the normal recruitment process. “It’s a bit soon to start speculating about the outcome of this, let alone other jobs which aren’t actually vacant.” Comment MORE ON BBC News" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: couple find human waste flowing
story: Couple find human waste flowing through garden and say its happened for decadesJill and Ralph Smith, from Godalming, Surrey, say they awoke to find human waste flowing into their garden for the second time this month - which usually happens after stormy weatherJill and Ralph Smith, from Surrey, say that human waste flows into their garden from sewage pipes following freak weather Image: BPM MEDIAByEleanor FlemingRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA couple awoke to find raw sewage flowing into their garden - and itaposs been happening for  years.Jill and Ralph Smith say human waste bursts from the manhole covers around their property in Godalming, Surrey, after freak weather conditions. They sat the local sewage network is too weak to handle torrential downpours, with high water levels creating pressure in the pipes causing the contents to spurt out, Surrey Live reports.The couple awoke on October  to find faeces covering their garden and patio. But they claim Thames Water didnapost clear up the mess until October .Following Thursdayaposs heavy rainfall, which sparked a Met Office amber weather warning, it happened again. Mr Smith, , told SurreyLive: When it rains, more water comes into the system and itaposs unable to cope. Thereaposs a backflow and pressure, and the sewage comes out into our garden. The sewage [was] still sitting there in my garden and on my patio [more than a week after the October  incident]. The odour is obnoxious and you can visibly see that itaposs sewage. Someone needs to take notice. It really has been going on for a long, long time and I can assure you that it will never get better. Itaposs only going to get worse, especially with all of these new buildings - industrial and domestic - being built in the area. The -year-old says he has been sending messages to Thames Water since  but nothing has solved the problem. Endless CCTV surveys have been carried out to look at the pipework, he said, adding that the water company have taken hundreds of photos.  Heaposs also appealed to local MP Angela Richardson, but received no response. Thames Water mentioned installing a part to the pipes, which will prevent waste overflowing into his garden, but he says they are yet to install it. A water level sensor installed around five or six years back helped on some occasions, but was not nearly effective enough, he said. Mr Smith said no solution has been proposed beyond that, but he will keep pushing until something is done to permanently fix it. He continued: If there is no further improvement in the Thames Water sewage system, itaposs only going to get worse. Money is the only thing that is going to solve it. He added: Itaposs a health hazard and [the sewage was] there for days - itaposs unfortunate. A Thames Water spokesperson said: Sewage flooding is horrible, and we sympathise with the couple for the long-running issues theyaposve experienced. The sewer network in the area is a combined system, meaning the pipes take foul water from loos, showers and washing machines, as well as rainwater. Climate change and population growth are putting increasing pressure on this local network. The area also suffers from high groundwater – this is where water in the soil can get into the network where two sections of pipe meet. As a result, the sewers can become overwhelmed, particularly during periods of intense rainfall, forcing diluted wastewater to come up through manholes. Blockages can be to blame for flooding, but Thames Water said it has carried out extensive investigations at the coupleaposs home and these have not shown any problems. The company said it visited the property on two occasions this month and found their pipe was clear and running normally. However, further CCTV investigations inside the pipe will be conducted. The spokesperson added: We will also discuss with them about fitting a apossewer depth monitorapos which will automatically alert us when the water level inside the pipe gets above a certain level. Thames Water said the coupleaposs case has been added to its Sewer Flooding History Database, which holds all reported flooding incidents within the Thames Water region. The database aims to categorise the reports by their cause, date and extent. story: Doctor not sure hes ever seen a child with so many injuries as dad denies murderArthur Labinjo-Hughess father Thomas Hughes and his partner Emma Tustin are accused of mistreating him before he suffered an "unsurvivable" brain injury at his home in Solihull, West Midlands, on June  Arthur was found unresponsive at a home in Shirley, Solihull, on June  last year Image: BPM MediaByCarl JacksonMatthew CooperCricket Trends WriterDanya Bazaraa:,  Oct An expert giving evidence in the trial of a six-year-old boy alleged to have been murdered after months of cruelty said it was not common to see so many bruises. Arthur Labinjo-Hughesaposs father Thomas Hughes and his partner Emma Tustin, who both deny murder, are accused of mistreating him before he suffered an unsurvivable brain injury at his home in Solihull, West Midlands, on June  . A forensic pathologist told the trial: Iaposm not sure Iaposve ever seen a child who has died at home with this many injuries to the head and face. On day  of the trial expert witness Dr Matt Lyall, a Home Office forensic pathologist, gave evidence.He took the court through the external injuries to Arthuraposs body, Birmingham Live reports. The court was shown graphics representing a childaposs head which displayed the bruising to Arthur. Prosecutor Jonas Hankin asked whether injuries to Arthuraposs jaw-line are typical of a six-year-old boy. Not normally, replied Dr Lyall. The expert confirmed, after discounting medical intervention marks and those with doubts about their origin, there are  areas of injury to Arthuraposs head and neck. Mr Hankin asked the expert: Is it commonplace to see this many bruises on a childaposs head and neck at post-mortem  Dr Lyall replied: Absolutely not. Iaposm not sure Iaposve ever seen a child who has died at home with this many injuries to the head and face. Arthur was found unresponsive at a home in Shirley, Solihull, on June  last year. He died at Birmingham Childrenaposs Hospital the following day.  A post-mortem examination confirmed his death was caused by a head injury. Arthuraposs father Thomas Hughes,  of Shirley, and Emma Tustin, , were subsequently arrested. They have both pleaded not guilty to murder. Tustin has admitted one count of child cruelty but has denied further charges of the same offence. Hughes also denies child cruelty offences. story: Exclusive: Ex-Premier League star who quit at  warns online racism may lead to player suicideMarvin Sordell says he has no regrets about walking away from his dream profession but warned that online abuse could lead to a player taking their own leMarvin Sordell has warned that sick online abuse could lead to a player taking their own le Image: PAByDave BurkeSenior reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct A former Premier League footballer who quit aged  after being bombarded with sickening racist abuse has warned giving bigots a free hit could lead to a player taking their own le.Marvin Sordell says he has no regrets about walking away from his dream profession - and said he was unsurprised after research by The Mirror found just a tiny fraction of people who post racist messages are charged or arrested.During his career the ex-England under- international, who represented Team GB at the  Olympics, frequently received hateful messages from complete strangers - many using their real names, confident they would not face any consequences. This took a huge toll on himself and his family, and Sordell believes lack of enforcement means racists have become more brazen knowing the risk of punishment is low. He said this could lead to a tragedyit is not addressed, stating: We shouldnapost have to wait until it happens until we act. In just two years the number of allegations of social media racism to  police forces in England and Wales soared by  per cent, with , in  alone. Figures released by  forces - the Met, Northumbria, Staffordshire, Surrey, Humberside Lincolnshire, Norfolk, Leicestershire, Cambridgeshire and Cleveland - show they had only charged  people between  and  despite receiving more than , complaints.  Sordell, now , said: Itaposs pretty clear to see that people can make whatever comments they want because they know that the likelihood of them being a found and b charged are very rare.If you think about the number of cases where people have faced consequences, you could probably Google them and name them all, which is pretty telling considering how much abuse is sent. In August the former Watford, Burnley and Bolton striker told a select committee of MPs that dealing with racism directed at players is not being treated as a priority.Iaposve been racially abused, Iaposve had death threats, Iaposve had threats of dferent kinds, he told The Mirror. At times it can be easier to deal with than others. One of the things that gets forgotten is that we all have families and friends who are on social media and they see it as well. Having to navigate that isnapost necessarily always taken into account. People see finances as a protection against reality, but itaposs not, reality is reality.  He echoed a warning by former England star Anton Ferdinand, who warned that abuse could lead to a player taking their own le. People donapost take into account how traumatic being on the end of any kind of abuse, particularly racist abuse, is - itaposs not something that should be taken lightly, Sordell said. When you say someone might take their own le, some might say itaposs not that serious, but thataposs always the case. We shouldnapost have to wait until it happens until we act.The former Premier League star, who now runs a production company and works as a public speaker and writer, has done a lot of advocacy work around mental health, having struggled with depression for many years.He said that educating offenders should be a key element of tackling online abuse.  Racism has been in football for as long as Iaposve known, and as long as the previous generation have known, but itaposs found a new medium, he said. We talk about kicking racism out, but all weaposve done is moved it to a dferent place. Sordell believes social networks need to step up and work with authorities to ensure those who post racist and abusive messages are punished. The fact is that every social media company has the IP address even without having the data on the iniduals they know where they are, he said. They have that capability. Nevertheless the former striker said he would receive hateful messages from accounts with peopleaposs real names on them.  Itaposs an alarm bell of where we are, he stated. It shows people feel like itaposs fine to do so, they donapost feel like theyaposre going to be punished. He believes every social network should very those who set up an account, eventheir real name is not visible on their profile. Sordell said: If I reported them to the police, the police should be able to find out who they are. The issue isnapost me being able to see their name, itaposs about them being held to account. Social media companies have faced mounting calls to act in recent months, with football clubs staging a boycott earlier this year and widespread condemnation of racism directed at Three Lions stars Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho and Bukayo Saka following the Euro  final. But Sordell said it is far too early to tellthis will cause a lasting impact.  Earlier this year fellow former Premier League star Anton Ferdinand told a Parliamentary select committee: My worry is what are the social media companies waiting for  Are they waiting for a high-profile footballer to kill themselves, or a member of their family to commit suicide. Is that what they are waiting for  Becausethat is what they are waiting for, that is too late. Letaposs deal with the issue now. The -year-old added that companies should use technology to identy inappropriate tweets before they are sent out, and talked about the need for an account owneraposs identity to be known, at least to the companies themselves. They donapost want to implement technology becauseI retweet a racist tweet that has been put my way, the frenzy around it is monetary to them, he said.The Mirror sent a list of questions to Facebook, asking for a breakdown of the number of racism complaints it had received, and the number of times it had provided details to police.The network says it is being proactive, removing more than  million pieces of hate speech content,  per cent before they were reported, and says incidents have falling slightly in the first three months of the year. It says it responds to valid legal requests for information from police, and is working with police chiefs to improve co-operation. A spokesperson said: “No one should have to experience racist abuse anywhere, and we don’t want it on Facebook or Instagram. We share the goal of holding people who share this content to account and we do this by taking action on content and accounts that break our rules and working with the police.We respond to valid legal requests for information as quickly as possible, and are confident that the information we provide is helpful to police investigations. We also encourage people to turn on Hidden Words, a tool which means no one has to see abuse in their comments or DMs. No one thing will fix this challenge overnight, but we’re committed to keeping our community safe from abuse.”A Twitter spokesperson said the company aposdoes not tolerate abuse or harassment of people on the basis of race, ethnicity, national origin, sexual orientation, gender, gender identity, religious affiliation, age, caste, disability or diseaseapos.The social media giant says it removes content that violates itaposs rules, which includes aposdehumanising languageapos, aposhateful imagery and emojisapos. Twitter has rules in place to address threats of violence, abuse and harassment and stressed it takes action when it finds accounts that violate them. However the spokesperson added that technology alone isnapost enough to solve the issue so they work with other organsiations to tackle racism and regularly meet with the Met Police.Anyone who wants to report violations can do so here https:help en forms law-enforcement Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON GooglePremier LeagueMarvin SordellEngland Under-sRacism" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Gran, , was psychotic and screaming after suspected drink spiking on date nightThe -year-old. from Hull, went out for a bite to eat with her husband but ended up feeling psychotic after a few sips of wine - leading her to believe her drink was tampered withThe -year-old woman was rushed to hospital and believes her drink was tampered with Image: hulldailymail WSByLucy Marshall:,  Oct A grandmotheraposs romantic date night left her suffering with concussion as she suspects her wine was spiked. The -year-old from Hull, went out for a bite to eat with her husband before ending up in an ambulance after her drink was allegedly tampered with.The woman, who wishes to remain anonymous, told Hull Live she fell straight down after leaving her local pub and suffered several episodes of hallucination.Now, a few months after the despicable experience, she wants to warn women that spiking is not exclusive to young people. Speaking out to warn others, she said she had planned a fun and much-awaited evening with her partner at a local restaurant before going to see a live band. I had only had a glass of wine in a trusted local restaurant. But I’ll never be able to order a glass of wine at a bar again, she said. We left a pub and as I got up and fell straight down and apparently hit my head hard, my husband was helped to get me up, we left and I fell again as we got outside. I vomited several times, and passed out too.  I then became psychotic. I didn’t know who my husband was. I was screaming at something in the room. I fought my poor husband who was only trying to help me. I only have snapshots of a few seconds at a time but the rest is a blank. An ambulance came to me and after a while we set off to the hospital. I could have died that night, I thank god I had my husband to look after me. Her husband rang an ambulance and her unstable condition meant it took a while to get her into the vehicle. She then had another another hallucination in the ambulance and had to stay in hospital overnight. She said the hospital believed Ketamine was in her drink and requested to view the CCTV from the bar following the -year-oldaposs fall, which caused her to become concussed. Now, the self-confessed shy grandma who said her behaviour that night was so far from normal, wants people of her generation to be aware when going out, whether with friends, family, or on dates. She added: I wanted my friends especially women of my generation to be aware. It’s really not the poor young girls. Itaposs anyone available to spike and they’ll do it. It’s beyond despicable. We all associate young people being spiked as hideous as that is. Never did I think that night out would end up as it did. It’s a disgusting thing to do to anyone. title: grieving family refused holiday refund
story: Grieving family refused holiday refund after mum-of-two, , dies of cancerDanielle Duffy, , died last Tuesday from a cancer of unknown origin, leaving her loved ones heartbroken. The family had booked a Sykes Cottages holiday but were initially denied a refundDanielle Duffy died five days after being diagnosed with cancer Image: LIVERPOOL ECHOByPatrick EdrichChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsA grieving family was refused a holiday refund when a mum-of-two died just five days after her cancer diagnosis. Danielle Duffy, , died last Tuesday from a cancer of unknown origin, leaving her loved ones heartbroken. The family had booked a holiday through Sykes Cottages to spend their birthdays on November  at Pennington Cottage in the Lake District. However, after Danielleaposs death, the womanaposs partner, Mark Whyte, tried to cancel the trip but was initially denied a refund.Despite previous correspondence from Booking showing a full refund would be given, Sykes Cottages refused to waive the £ cancellation charges, despite the tragic circumstances, the Liverpool Echo reports. Markaposs dad, Adrian Whyte, said Sykes Cottages hadnapost shown any empathy and seemed keen to profit from this tragic loss. The -year-old said: Itaposs all a little confusing. On Booking it said it was cancelled out, but when we tried to get the refund it said we werenapost eligible. Itaposs a cottage in Ambleside and Iaposm pretty sure the property will backfill the booking. Theyaposre basically saying theyaposll take the money, but the booking is cancelled. After the ECHO contacted Sykes Cottages, they said they would be happy to provide a refund to the grief-stricken family.  A spokesperson for Sykes Cottages told the ECHO: Given the circumstances, we have waived the cancellation charge and apologise for any upset this has caused Mr Whyte. Adrian said there had been ambiguity in his correspondence with Sykes and when he previously asked what was happening with a refund, he was told they would not be getting one. He said he could understand Sykes refusing a refundsomeone changes their mind about their booking, but felt it was unempathetic to do so when someone didnapost know they were ill and then died. He added: It may well be the first time theyaposve come across a situation like this, buttheyaposre agents for , properties, I would have imagined theyaposve come across this before.  I just hope in the future they will be a little bit more empathetic towards people in a similar situation. Danielle was a much-loved teacher at St Julieaposs Catholic High School in Woolton, Liverpool. She first went to her GP after feeling unwell in August, and after undergoing tests was diagnosed with cancer of unknown origin on October  at Whiston Hospital. The diagnosis means doctors do not know where cancer started in the body before it spread to other areas. The woman died just five days after being diagnosed with cancer. Danielleaposs sister Lisa Wellbeloved, , said her sister was her best friend and an amazing mum to her children Daniel, seven, and Isabella, three. She added: Everything she did was for her children, she adored them. They are heartbroken, but theyaposve got a permanentangel now. title: its both exciting soothing wild
story: It’s both exciting and soothing - the wild new hobby one woman swears byAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newWould you try lake swimming AdvertorialByEimear OHagan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct If we’ve learnt anything over the past year and a half, it’s that you never know what’s around the corner, so itaposs important to seize opportunities, push ourselves out of our comfort zone and live for the moment. KFC is doing just that by encouraging people to spice things up to mark the launch of its tasty new Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only. So to join in the fun, weaposre championing people who have challenged themselves to try new things, including Jenny Holden who has ed head first into wild swimming. The forty-seven-year-old mum of ten-year-old twins from Lichfield, Staffordshire, explains that she was in search of a new challenge, and one that would bring some excitement to her le.  ‘With my children a bit older, and less dependent on me, I found myself with a little bit more time for myself, and I wanted to use it doing something fun,’ says Jenny who runs her own PR company Chorus Communications. ‘Especially post lockdowns, with so much time spent at home, being sedentary and growing bored of my normal activities, I was craving a new hobby, and one that would really exhilarate me.’ A friend suggested Jenny try wild swimming at a quarry near her home and Jenny decided to give it a go, albeit with some nerves. ‘I’m a keen swimmer but the idea of swimming in that sort of environment was completely new to me. Also, wouldn’t it be freezing  I was intrigued enough to give it a go though, and took my first dip in August with one of my sons. ‘Plunging into the water, my first thought was – wow it’s cold! But actually, once you become acclimatised to the water temperature it feels wonderful. That first swim was really memorable, I came out of the water feeling revived and invigorated, and I knew I was a convert.’ Jenny persuaded three friends to form a wild swim gang with her and since August they have met weekly for a dip. ‘I don’t wear a wetsuit, it’s too much faff getting in and out of one, just a swimsuit and now I look forward to my swim all week. ‘Front crawling through open water, surrounded by the sounds and sights nature, it’s so amazing and it washes away the stresses of the week. It’s nothing like swimming in a pool, it’s both exciting and soothing, brilliant for body and mind. ‘It’s definitely going to get a bit nippier as we go into winter but I’m ready for the challenge!’ So in the spirit of taking the plunge and trying something new, e into a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it is only around for a limited period, available until November .Download the app, head in store or order online. story: Newlyweds miss honeymoon by just  minutes after Covid test confusion at airportAdrian and Jane Smith, from Doncaster, paid £, for their dream honeymoon to Spain, and wanted to take son Brandon with them - but thanks to a Covid- test mix up were barred from even getting on the plane.Adrian and Jane Smith, from Doncaster, paid £, for their dream honeymoon to Spain, and wanted to take son Brandon with them Image: ITV NEWSByKate Buck:,  Oct | commentsA devastated newlywed couple say they missed their honeymoon by just  minutes after being told their sonaposs PCR Covid- test was invalid. Adrian and Jane Smith, from Doncaster, paid £, for their dream honeymoon to Spain, and wanted to take son Brandon with them.As he is unvaccinated, Brandon needed a negative PCR test, so Adrian and Jane paid for the private test provider suggested by Tui themselves. But when they arrived at Doncaster Airport the family were told they were not allowed to board the plane - all because Brandonaposs test was invalid, ITV News reports. The rules of the test stated that the test had to be taken  hours before the departure time of the plane - but this was incorrect. Have you experienced anything similar trying to travel  Get in touch at webnews@mirrorIt was actually the time of arrival in Spain that mattered, meaning the test was just  minutes out of date for their landing.Adrian said: There were two very clear statements, one of them said step two take the test and it says up to  hours before the departure of the plane take the sample and register the sample.So it was very clear that it said departure of the plane not the arrival time in Spain, unfortunately that turned out to be incorrect information. So for being outside the  day time limit by around  minutes, the couple were forced tohome and abandon their trip.In a statement TUI told ITV:Weaposre very sorry the Smith family were unable to travel on their honeymoon due to the information on our testing partners website, and understand how disappointing this must have been. We have refunded their holiday, all testing costs, and are offering an additional voucher towards their next holiday as an apology for the upset caused.Jane said the pair were: Devastated, absolutely gutted, shocked. We have lost our honeymoon. We can never rewind the clock and go back to that time now unfortunately.Tui have claimed the staff were supportive and did all they could to help while they simply stood there and watched us stranded in the airport itaposs just disgusting really. Their story comes to light just days before the rules for vaccinated Brits arriving into the UK from abroad will change.From October , If you are fully vaccinated, then according to the Department for Transport, before you travel to England you must:book and pay for a day  COVID- test – to be taken after arrival in England. You need to book this test before you travel complete a passenger locator form – to be completed in the  hours before you arrive in EnglandYou do not need to take a PCR test before ing, as you were required to do so previously. If you are not fully vaccinated you must take a Covid- test in the three days before yourto the UK, as well as complete the steps above. If you are visiting a red list country, or have visited one in transit on our way home from one, then you are required to:take a COVID- test – you must take the test in the  days before you travel to the UK book a quarantine hotel package, including  COVID- tests. complete a passenger locator formThis is regardless ofyou are fully vaccinated or not. If arriving in England, you can use the apostest-to-releaseapos scheme on day five. You must pay the private test provider for this. story: One in seven young women report being spiked as attacks become an epidemicThe survey of  women aged - by the Alcohol Education Trust found  per cent of victims did not tell the police - and of the ones who told police, half said nothing happenedOne in seven young women have reported being spiked Image: Getty Images Monkey BusinessByLucy ThorntonAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsSpiking of drinks has become an “epidemic”, with one in seven young women reporting having been targeted.The survey of  -s by the Alcohol Education Trust found % of victims did not tell the police. Of those who did, half said nothing happened as a result. AET head Helena Conibear called for bars and clubs to search people at the door and to have testing kits available on site. Ms Conibear added: “Our poll revealed % of drinks were spiked at private parties, % in nightclubs, % in bars and % at festivals. This can happen to anyone, anywhere and to any drink. Have you been affected by this story  Get in touch at webnews@mirror“It really is an epidemic.” She said most spiking cases did not lead to assault or robbery.Demanding action, students plan a clubs boycott on Wednesday. Police report  cases of drink spiking in September October, and  of injection. Home Secretary Priti Patel has asked the police to assess the problem.Two men have been detained in Nottingham and one in Lincoln by police investigating spiking attacks.  The two men in Nottingham - aged  and  - were detained on Friday morning on ‘suspicion of conspiracy to administer poison with intent to injure, annoy or aggrieve’. The arrests were made after officers studied CCTV footage working closely with venues in the city, police said. Superintendent Kathryn Craner, of Nottinghamshire Police, said: “These two arrests come after a plea from myself and the force for people to come forward and report any incidents to us.  “We have now arrested two men this morningon suspicion of conspiracy to administer poison and both are still in custody as our enquiries continue. “I would like to reiterate that these arrests have not been made in connection with a specic case or incident reported to us over the last few weeks of both drink spiking and spiking by a needle.” But Nottinghamshire Police did confirm they had received three new reports in the last  hours of being “spiked with a needle” - taking the total of such incidents under investigation to .The NHS website provides some guidelines on what to doyour skin has been punctured with a used needle. They advise to aposwash the wound using running water and plenty of soapapos, aposdry the wound and cover it with a waterproof plaster or dressingapos and to not scrub the wound or suck any blood. Nottingham Policeaposs websites has some guidance on what to doyour drink has been spiked, but they currently do not have any guidelines on being injected. They advise to: Tell the people you’re with and make sure you’re someone where you feel safe. Alert a member of staff at the pub or club you are at. If you feel unwell you should seek medical attention immediately and tell them that you believe your drink has been spiked. They said a number of the victims reported being spiked by some sort of injection and have reported effects “consistent with a substance being administered”. University of Nottingham student, Sarah Buckle, has told how she woke up in hospital with no memory of how she got there and throbbing pain in her hand. The -year-old later discovered she had been possibly spiked with a needle to the back of her hand while at a nightclub. Fourteen women and one man have reported to police they believe they had been spiked with a sharp object in the region. Earlier this week Nottinghamshire police arrested a -year-old man who has been released on bail as enquiries continue into spiking by needle continue. The force said they would be deploying more officers into Nottingham city centre, with a police dog operation planned for Saturday night and plain-clothes officers on duty. Lincolnshire Police said a -year-old man was detained “on suspicion of possession of drugs with intent to administer them” at about am on Friday. The arrest came after what the force called “swt and proactive work in partnership from the staff at a Lincoln nightclub”, although they did not name the venue. The suspected offence “doesn’t involve a needle”, police said. Lincolnshire’s police and crime commissioner Marc Jones said: “We cannot accept people being unsafe when they go out with friends for a drink. “This arrest should send a huge signal to those would-be criminals who look to prey on our community in this despicable way.” Devon and Cornwall Police said they were investigating reports of a woman being attacked with a needle in Fever  Boutique in Exeter on Saturday, October th. The spate of reported incidents prompted Home Secretary Priti Patel to ask police forces to assess the scale of the problem. A petition launched last week to make it a legal requirement for nightclubs to thoroughly search people on entry has now gained more than , signatures. Police have said there have been around  confirmed reports across September and October of drink spiking and  reports of some form of injection. National Police Chiefsapos Council lead for drugs, Deputy Chief Constable Jason Harwin, said: There are both male and female victims, though the majority have been young women. Alleged offences have taken place at licensed premises and private parties. He added: Clearly these reports are very concerning. We are working at pace with forces, law enforcement agencies such as the NCA and other partners including the Home Office and universities to understand the scale of offending, establish any links between the allegations and ultimately bring any identied offenders to justice. Ahead of the weekend, and looking further to the Halloween weekend, please be assured that forces are working closer than ever before with pubs and clubs to help tackle the issue and encouraging premises to increase searches at entry points to the venues. Police are also working with venues to make sure all staff are alert to the issue and to advise them of what to dothey see signs of spiking. We would encourage anyone who believes they have been a victim or witness to spiking, in any form, to contact their local police force. Any reports of spiking will be investigated and taken seriously. title: overweight mum drops 9 stone
story: Overweight mum drops  stone over fears Covid- would take her from daughterRachel Walkingshaw-McGuinness, , worried that carrying  stones and lbs made her susceptible to catching Covid- and would leave her daughter without a mother Image: MERCURY PRESSByLouie Smith:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments An overweight woman who feared Covid would leave her daughter without a mum has lost nine stone in eight months.Rachel Walkingshaw-McGuinness, , worried that carrying  stones and lbs made her susceptible to the virus. So she began exercising to ensure she would be around to raise daughter Poppy, one.Since starting her weight loss plan last December Rachel has gone from size  to a st lb size ten.She said: “I was terried at the thought of catching the virus and dying. “I didn’t want Poppy to end up with zero memories of me. “One night, I put my daughter to bed and I was very out of breath from the stairs.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter “It was even scarier when my husband got the virus despite being on the shielding list.” Rachel, from Newport, Wales says she had always been overweight. But the death of her mum Jacqueline Murphy, , in  made the issue worse. The problem became so bad that she tried to avoid mum and baby groups because she struggled to complete the activities. Independent consultant Rachel explained: “I comfort ate a lot and used food as a way to quash my emotions. “I’d be spending well over £ a week on food alone, it was so easy to just go into McDonald’s for lunch whilst I was working.  “I’d be having a large Big Mac meal, mozzarella dippers, a mayo chicken burger and a full size McFlurry all to myself. “Each night, I’d be eating a full pack of chocolate Digestives.” Last December Rachel, who lives with husband Jamie, , started The : Diet plan by Cambridge Weight Plan. She was too embarrassed to go to the gym so began exercising by going on short walks. She has now taken up running and yoga and is training for a k event. Rachel added: “My goal was to be able to watch Poppy grow up, to play with her, and run around with her in the park.  “I love my new body and the confidence I’ve gained from shedding the weight. “I never thought I’d be able to sit on the swings with my little girl. “In every aspect of my le, who I am now is completely dferent to how I used to feel.” DIET AT HEAVIEST BREAKFAST - Four crumpets with butter and jam LUNCH - Carbonara pasta, or other large dish, with big side such as garlic bread DINNER - Dominoes Takeaway One large pizza, side of garlic bread, dough balls, chicken strips and a full size tub of Ben and Jerry’s ice cream. SNACKS - Three bars of chocolate, full size bag of Haribo, whole pack of biscuits, packet of crisps. DRINKS - Large Latte’s from Costa and full fat fizzy drinks. CURRENT DIET BREAKFAST - Vanilla shake with a shot of coffee and protein yoghurt with berries. LUNCH - Fish cake and salad or a chicken salad. DINNER - Low carb meal: fish with chargrilled vegetables, or roast dinner, or something like Quorn nuggets with vegetables and rice. SNACKS - Pop squares, or snacks like high protein crisps. story: Price of groceries jumps  per cent - list of food that has gone up in price the mostSupermarket bosses have largely shielded shoppers from the worst of a surge in costs in a desperate bid to keep customers, but now it could hit retailers with higher prices on goodsThe price of some groceries has jumped by  per cent Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByGraham HiscottHead of BusinessAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments The price of some groceries has jumped by  per cent, adding to the cost of living crisis.Apples and margarine are among the goods that have got much dearer. Supermarket bosses, desperate to keep customers, have largely shielded shoppers from the worst of a surge in costs.But there are signs higher costs are being passed on. Marmite maker Unilever is the latest big supplier to warn it could hit retailers with higher prices.After months of falling food prices, food inflation – how much prices are rising year-on-year – almost tripled from .% in August to .% in September, the Office for National Statistics said. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter A close look at the stats shows some items rose sharply year-on-year. Pork sausages have gone from £. to £. a kilo – a % jump. Pears have soared % to £. and apples have surged % to £.. Margarine has also risen % – with a typical g tub now costing £.. Experts warn food inflation could carry on rising into next year.  Investment group Shore Capital predicts prices will jump as much as % partway through . Clive Black, one of its research analysts, said: “Some suppliers that raised prices in the summer are... already necessarily coming back for more given the inflationary forces.” He added those in the industry may end up with “no more slack to cut”. He said: “With rising demands from supply chains around animal welfare..., safety, sustainability and well-being, in future years shoppers will have to pay more for their food.” Rising food bills will add to the pressure on millions of households having to pay higher energy prices.Those hardest hit have also lost the £ a week Universal Credit uplt.Comment MORE ON Office for National StatisticsSupermarkets" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our money-saving tips and top offers direct to your inbox with the Mirror Money newsletterInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: queen must slow down health
story: Exclusive: Queens health wobbles are concerning, admits royal expertCancelling her trip to Northern Ireland, using a stick and giving up her nightly tipple - Queen Elizabeths minor wobbles paint a worrying picture, writes Royal commentator and author Robert JobsonThese wobbles are an important reminder that despite saying youre as young as you feel, Her Majesty is as old as her  years Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByRobert Jobson:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsOne of the reasons Prince Philip stepped back from royal duties at  was because he didn’t want the Palace putting out daily bulletins about the state of his healthhe didn’t feel up to doing an engagement on a particular day. He couldn’t stand all the brouhaha that went with updates about his health and rightly found it “bloody intrusive”. Eventually, he felt he has done his bit as the Queen’s consort and duly retired. As monarch and head of state, Queen Elizabeth II doesn’t really have that option. Her schedule has been tailored to take her great age into consideration. But nobody can account for daily changes in an elderly person’s physical health. One day they can feel great, the next dreadful.Since emerging from lockdown and the death of her husband, the Queen has thrown herself into work and had a busy schedule.This month since ing from her annual summer break in Balmoral, she seems to have been a constant presence in our newspapers and online. We should not, therefore, be hugely surprised by the advice from her medical household that she should rest up for a few days.Nor that she spent last night in hospital while apospreliminary checksapos took place – her doctors have not gone into detail. Buckingham Palace was forced to make a public statement when a planned two-day trip – to mark the centenary of partition in Northern Ireland – was cancelled.The previous night the Queen attended a reception at Windsor Castle and looked sprightly and certainly not sickly. Buckingham Palace also released video of her virtual audience with the new Governor-General of New Zealand. But her hospitalisation followed a very busy period – a speech at the opening of the Welsh Parliament and a service at Westminster Abbey marking the work of the Royal British Legion.At the Abbey she was pictured using a cane for the first time. The Palace said she was using it for her “comfort”.This coupled with the fact that she has given up her favourite alcohol tipple – a strong early evening Martini – on doctors’ advice, has got some very commentators worried. But London Bridge is NOT falling down and Her Majesty is in fine fettle, I am told.She is determined to host world leaders at COP in Glasgow at the end of the month.But these wobbles are an important reminder that despite saying “you’re as young as you feel”, Her Majesty is as old as her  years.She is a robust lady, a dedicated lady, and a brilliant wise head of state. She must, therefore, recognise, as her late husband did, that she is only human and she must pace herself going forward - for all our sakes. news uk-news queens-aides-accused-covering-up-"BBCs Nicholas Witchell hits out at Queens health statementByChris KitchingSenior News Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe Queenaposs aides have been accused of trying to cover up her stay in hospital and misleading the nation over her the state of her health.Buckingham Palace has faced growing criticism for keeping the hospital stay a secret, with a scathing attack launched by a BBC royal correspondent who questioned how much the Palace could be trusted. The -year-old monarch was admitted to King Edward VII hospital in London on Wednesday afternoon and stayed overnight for tests. The Palace told journalists the Queen had been advised to rest and remained at Windsor Castle, but more than  hours later confirmed she had been taken to the private hospital.  A trip to Northern Ireland was cancelled at the last minute. The royal standard continued to fly at the castle after the Queen had left.A royal source denied it remained flying as part of a cover-up, telling the Daily Mail the standard did not move to every building the Queen visited.Despite the hospital stay, the source said, Windsor had remained the Queen’s residence. BBC royal correspondent Nicholas Witchell said journalists and Brits aposweren’t given the complete pictureapos. He added: The problem, it seems to me, is that rumour and misinformation always thrive in the absence of proper, accurate and trustworthy information. Royal commentator and former BBC journalist Peter Hunt alleged there had been a ‘failed attempt’ to cover up the Queenaposs hospital stay. He said: The media’s faith in the veracity of royal communications will have been sorely tested by the failed attempt to hide the fact the Queen spent a night in hospital. Buckingham Palace can ill afford a breakdown in trust, given all they’re dealing with. A spokesman for the Palace declined to comment on the cover-up claims.  Joe Little, managing editor of Majesty Magazine, said the issue of revealing details about the monarch’s health is problematic: “This is a tricky one because the Queen does have a right to a certain degree of privacy, but on the other hand she’s head of state. “So does that entitle us to know exactly what ailments she may or may not have  It’s a very dficult one to get the balance right for the satisfaction of everybody.” Royal author Penny Junor said the Palace’s decision not to announce the hospital visit prevented unfounded rumours circulating. She said: “I’m not surprised they did that, otherwise there would be speculation. People would be putting her in her grave long before she’s ready for it.” It is understood the Queen was due to stay in hospital for only a short period while seen by specialists, so the development was not announced by the Palace at the time, and protecting her medical privacy was also a consideration. The overnight admittance was for “practical reasons”, a source said. It is said the Queen was back at her desk and doing light duties after ing to Windsor. A Buckingham Palace spokesman said late on Thursday night: “Following medical advice to rest for a few days, the Queen attended hospital on Wednesday afternoon for some preliminary investigations, ing to Windsor Castle at lunchtime today, and remains in good spirits.”Sources told Russell Myers, the Mirroraposs Royal Editor, that she was expected to have visitors, including family, this weekend, but engagements in next weekaposs diary have been put on hold.It was unclear whether she would attend the COP climate summit in Glasgow. news uk-news queens-appearance-un-climate-summit-"Queen discusses COP with Elin Jones and the Duchess of WalesByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments The Queen’s appearance in front of world leaders at the UN Climate Change Conference is in the balance, after she was ordered by doctors to rest until she receives the results of “preliminary investigations”.The -year-old monarch was forced to spend the night in hospital on Wednesday, after specialist doctors performed a series of tests at the King Edward VII hospital in Marylebone, London. Buckingham Palace said medics took an “understandably cautious approach”, adding the Queen’s admission was for “practical reasons”, before she ed home to Windsor Castle on Thursday afternoon. A Palace source said the results of the initial tests “could result in the need for further examinations….or confirm that no further tests are necessary”. Get the Mirroraposs daily newsletter for all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up The source added: “Clearly the doctors are looking at something during their preliminary investigations.” The Queen is understood to be committed to attending COP conference in Glasgow on November , alongside son Prince Charles and grandson Prince William, as they jointly encourage world leaders to take action on the global climate emergency.But it emerged on Friday that the Queen will only take on “light duties”, until she speaks to doctors.A palace source said: “The Queen is in good spirits and will continue to take a period of rest over the next few days.  “She will be guided by her doctors on what is appropriate in terms of her duties.” Her Majesty is understood to have several engagements in her diary for next week which have been put on hold, while an assessment on her attendance at COP will be taken in due course, The Mirror understands.Downing Street declined to say whether Prime Minister Boris Johnson held his weekly audience with the monarch on Wednesday, but so far it has not been listed in the Court Circular, the official record of royal engagements. The spokesman said: “The Prime Minister’s best wishes have been passed on to Her Majesty.” Sources confirmed the Queen is accommodating visitors over the weekend from “family who live nearby”. Her youngest son Edward, his we Sophie and their children Louise and James live in Bagshot Park in Surrey, which is just  miles away. Scandal-hit Prince Andrew, who also lives close to the Queen at his Royal Lodge home on the Windsor Estate, is also understood to be planning to visit his mother in the coming days.  The Queen was forced to “reluctantly” cancel a two day trip to Northern Ireland on Wednesday morning, less than five hours before she was due to arrive. Alongside the announcement that the Queen would not travel, Buckingham Palace said she would “rest for the next few days” at Windsor Castle. In the early afternoon the monarch was seen walking her dogs on the Windsor Estate, while it later emerged she was taken to hospital in London by car later in the day. Courtiers insisted Her Majesty was forced to stay overnight after it became too late to make the  mile journey home to Windsor. But the Palace only confirmed the Queen’s stay at pm on Thursday, more than five hours after she had ed to Windsor Castle. The Queen’s admittance was her first overnight stay in hospital since she spent a night at the private clinic in  when she was treated for the symptoms of gastroenteritis. A palace spokesman did not reveal the nature of the Queen’s investigations, but stressed the tests were “not Covid-related”. The Queen is double-vaccinated and is understood to have had her booster jab. Joe Little, managing editor of Majesty Magazine, said the issue of revealing details about the monarch’s health is problematic: “This is a tricky one because the Queen does have a right to a certain degree of privacy, but on the other hand she’s head of state. “So does that entitle us to know exactly what ailments she may or may not have  “It’s a very dficult one to get the balance right for the satisfaction of everybody.” Comment MORE ON QueenRoyal FamilyThe QueenBoris JohnsonPrince Andrew, Duke of YorkPrince WilliamPrince Charles, Prince of WalesBuckingham PalaceHospitalsClimate changePolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Queen sends message she is not stepping down after snubbing Oldie of Year awardThe Queen politely turned down the Oldie of the Year award saying "you are as old as you feel" and royal biographer Angela Levin believes that was intended to show she has no plans to stop doing her duty just yetThe Queen is not planning to step down believes Angela Levin based on her refusing the Oldie of the Year award Image: Getty ImagesByTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe Queen showed she is not stepping down by refusing the Oldie of the Year award, a royal biographer has claimed. The -year-old monarch reportedly turned down the award “politely but firmly” that she was offered by Oldie magazine and instead replied with her “warmest best wishes”. Author Gyles Brandreth, chairman of the awards, wrote to the monarch askingshe would accept the title. Her assistant private secretary Tom Laing-Baker wrote back: “Her majesty believes you are as old as you feel, as such The Queen does not believe she meets the relevant criteria to be able to accept, and hopes you will find a more worthy recipient.” The rejection came just days before a health scare that saw the long-serving royal cancel an overseas trip.Now royal biographer Angela Levin said that the line “you are only as old as you feel” is an indication that she is not planning to step down. She tweeted: “I think that the Queenaposs comment that you are as old as you feel is also a nudge to let us all know she is not going to step down as Monarch.” In an earlier post she said the Queen was “absolutely spot on” with her reply to being offered the award. It comes as the Queen cancelled a trip to Northern Ireland this week after she “reluctantly accepted medical advice to rest for the next few days,” said Buckingham Palace. But reports from royal circles have said that she is prioritising being ready to attend the COP climate change conference in Glasgow later this month. Brandreth, who was joined by the Duchess of Cornwall for The Oldie’s ceremony at The Savoy hotel in London last Tuesday, said the reply from the Queen was “lovely”.  He added: “Perhaps in the future we will sound out Her Majesty once more.”Camilla, , spoke at the awards ceremony and joked about ageing, according to the Express.She said: I think those of us who have already passed our three score years and ten have to acknowledge that there are certain disadvantages to growing older. Adding: There are times, I know, when we all experience those senior moments.” Buckingham Palace has faced growing criticism for keeping the hospital stay a secret, with a scathing attack launched by a BBC royal correspondent who questioned how much the Palace could be trusted. The -year-old monarch was admitted to King Edward VII hospital in London on Wednesday afternoon and stayed overnight for tests.  The Palace told journalists the Queen had been advised to rest and remained at Windsor Castle, but more than  hours later confirmed she had been taken to the private hospital. A trip to Northern Ireland was cancelled at the last minute. The royal standard continued to fly at the castle after the Queen had left. A royal source denied it remained flying as part of a cover-up, telling the Daily Mail the standard did not move to every building the Queen visited. Despite the hospital stay, the source said, Windsor had remained the Queen’s residence. BBC royal correspondent Nicholas Witchell said journalists and Brits aposweren’t given the complete pictureapos. He added: The problem, it seems to me, is that rumour and misinformation always thrive in the absence of proper, accurate and trustworthy information. Royal commentator and former BBC journalist Peter Hunt alleged there had been a ‘failed attempt’ to cover up the Queenaposs hospital stay. He said: The media’s faith in the veracity of royal communications will have been sorely tested by the failed attempt to hide the fact the Queen spent a night in hospital. Buckingham Palace can ill afford a breakdown in trust, given all they’re dealing with. A spokesman for the Palace declined to comment on the cover-up claims. story: Royal expert predicts what Prince Philip wouldve told Queen amid new health battleNews of the unexpected hospital stay was announced by Buckingham Palace last night, less than  hours after it emerged that the Queen would no longer be able to visit Northern IrelandAn expert has said Prince Philip would have encouraged the Queen to attend fewer engagements Image: Tim Graham Getty ImagesByMirror:,  Oct | commentsPrince Philip would have encouraged the Queen to attend fewer engagements, a royal expert has claimed, after it emerged the monarch has spent a night being tested in hospital. Angela Levin, a royal biographer, has said Prince Philip, who died at the age of  back in April, would have taken the reigns and exercised a “bit of control”. Ms Levin said the Duke of Edinburgh would likely have said “Look, stop it, donapost go to so many engagements and relax a bit.” Get the Mirroraposs daily newsletter for all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up  Speaking of the news that the -year-old monarch underwent “preliminary investigations” after cancellinga planned trip to Northern Ireland this week , Ms Levin said the Queen was facing a “fight between her head and her body”. She also suspected there was a religious aspect to this struggle, after the Queen vowed at her Coronation in  that God would help her fulfil her role as the head of state until she died. News of the unexpected hospital stay was announced by Buckingham Palace last night, less than  hours after it emerged that she would no longer be able to visit Northern Ireland. A Palace spokesperson said: “Following medical advice to rest for a few days, The Queen attended hospital on Wednesday afternoon for some preliminary investigations, ing to Windsor Castle at lunchtime today, and remains in good spirits.” It followed a statement from the palace about the cancelled trip, on which a spokesperson said: “The Queen has reluctantly accepted medical advice to rest for the next few days”. “Her Majesty is in good spirits and is disappointed that she will no longer be able to visit Northern Ireland. “The Queen sends her warmest good wishes to the people of Northern Ireland, and looks forward to visiting in the future.” According to reports from The Sun, it is understood that the Wednesday afternoon trip to private King Edward VII’s Hospital in London on was expected to be for some “preliminary investigations”. The overnight stay was reportedly for practical purposes. Speaking to talkRadio today, Ms Levin suggested it would be bestthe Queen was encouraged to take a step backwards, or sideways, in order to allow her body to recover from the many engagements she undertakes.  “I think itaposs a fight between her head and her body, because she wants to do it, she feels she can, sheaposs very articulate, sheaposs absolutely spot on with everything she says, but her body is  years old,” Ms Levin said. “I think she thinks she does it best [compared to other royals] and sheaposs the most experienced, but I think the main thing is the religious one, that when she was  and she said that she would do her best to be the Queen and with Godaposs help she would do it until she died.” Ms Levin suggested breaking this promise would make the Queen feel “very bad” as she is devout. “However, the Pope has stepped back, he retired for the first time [Benedict XVI in ] - and popes are not supposed to leave their job until they die too, and I think you have to take into consideration that people live much longer than they did in  [when she married Prince Philip].” On reports that the Queen had given up alcohol, Ms Levin thought there could be an emotional connection. The Monarch used to share a Dubonnet with ious mixtures with her husband, she said, which was a part of their relationship. Ms Levin suggested the drink “no longer has the same taste” because Philip wasn’t around anymore to pour it. According to a statement from the Palace, the Queen is now in “good spirits” and now recovering at Windsor Castle - where she has spent most of the last  months due to thecoronaviruspandemic.She is expected to spend the rest of the week recovering. It is the first time she has stayed in hospital overnight for eight years. Courtiers believe the cancellation of the Queenaposs trip will serve as a reminder that the head of state - at the age of  - cannot do what was expected of her  or  years ago. In recent weeks she has for the first time been seen walking with a stick at public engagements.The Queen remains committed to attending theCOP climate change summitin Glasgow on November , courtiers said.Her Majesty has had a jam packed schedule of engagements since ing from her summer break at Balmoral. She took on at least  engagements since the start of the month, visiting Scotland and Wales for the official opening of the Parliaments. It is understood that courtiers are keeping a close eye on the Queen’s diary moving forward so that she has the correct amount of time to recuperate from her schedule.It emerged this week that the Queenturned down the ‘Oldie of the Year’ trophybecause she feels she does not meet the criteria, believing you are only as old as you feel.A royal source said: “Her Majesty doesn’t know any other pace than full on and used to being incredibly busy, especially of late, but perhaps it is in her best interests that she takes this time to rest and recuperate before she starts once again.” Sources said the Queen will no doubt have to take on board the advice of her doctors as she battles against wanting to “do things full on” after being released from coronavirus restrictions. title: schoolgirl 14 loses finger jumping
story: Schoolgirl, , loses finger jumping fence while escaping isolation with palsTia Meggett, , escaped isolation with three other girls at The Gainsborough Academy on October  and didnt realise she had lost her finger until friends pointed out she was bleedingTia Meggett lost her right-hand ring finger when she jumped a fence escaping isolation with her friends Image: Nicola Kelly   MEN MediaByOliver PridmoreAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA teenage girl has lost her finger after jumping a school fence. Tia Meggett, , escaped isolation at The Gainsborough Academy on October  with three other girls.They managed to leave the unit through a fire exit and jump a fence, but Tia caught her right-hand ring finger as she did, LincolnshireLive reports. Once she made it to the other side, Tiaaposs friends says she was bleeding and when she looked down she saw her finger missing. The school says it is now reviewing its procedures in light of the horrying incident. Mum Nicola Kelly said: It was at about am that this happened and the school rang me at around .am. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter They said that something had happened to Tia but that she would only need a few stitches. So my neighbour took me down to the school straight away and when I got there, Tia was in the back of a teacheraposs car with her hand in the air. The headteacher was there and they just passed me a bowl that had bags of frozen sweetcorn in it and when I lted the bags up, Tiaaposs finger was there. I donapost know whether what they told me on the phone was just so I didnapost panic or what, but it was quite obviously going to be more than a few stitches. The school said they called an ambulance but they said the wait would take too long. Nicola then accompanied the teachers who drove Tia to Lincoln County Hospital. Tia was eventually transferred to the Royal Derby Hospital she underwent an operation to have her finger amputated on October . Nicola added: When I first saw her at the school she was just in a complete state of shock I think. Sheaposs doing as well as she can do now in the circumstances, but Iaposm not going to be sending her back to the school. Thereaposs a video that has been going around of when she jumped the fence and there have been some nasty comments that she just doesnapost need. So the school have loaned her a laptop and Iaposm going to seeI can work out some sort of arrangement with them for her to be taught at home. My main issue is how she and the other girls managed to get out of the school, and what this teacher in their classroom was actually doingthey managed to get out of the fire exit. Iaposm not happy with them at all and I think there are so many ways that they could have handled this better and more sensitively. Tiaaposs now having to adapt to not having one of her fingers and she was a teenager girl who liked painting her nails and everything - so this is really upsetting. Martin Smith, the assistant director for education at Lincolnshire County Council, said: The academy has informed us of the incident, which we realise has been upsetting for the family. title: whats going wrong uk booster
story: Whats going wrong with UK booster jab rollout - from low take-up to missing ministerThe UKs booster jab rollout has stuttered and faltered since the beginning despite it being a vital part of the defence against Covid- this winterVaccine minister Maggie Throup has not made a single national appearance Image: Derby ByKieren Williams:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe UK’s booster jab rollout has faltered on a number of fronts getting jabs into arms - contrasting to the country’s success earlier in the year. Despite it long being clear a booster jab programme would be needed, the UK government and scientic advisors were slow off the mark. Israel began their own booster programme in August, offering it to children as young as , but it took the UK almost three more weeks to begin their own. Data shows the jab offers massively improved protection against the virus and yet the booster has not been met with the same enthusiasm as the initial rollout.With winter approaching it is even more important than ever that everyone who is eligible gets their booster jab. The Mirror has taken a look at what’s going wrong with the UK’s booster jab rollout.  Why do we need boosters  Covid vaccines offer an impressive defence against the virus, but do not guarantee  per cent protection. You are still at risk of catching it and even though your chance of serious hospitalisation and death are dramatically reduced, you can pass it on or get Long Covid yourself. Added to that, studies show double-jab protection starts to wane from around five months after the second dose. King’s College London found that the effectiveness of the AstraZeneca jab against catching the virus fell from  per cent to  per cent at four to five months after a second dose. The third jab bolsters that protection, with some thinking they may become an annual thing, like the flu jab.To give you an idea of its effectiveness, the Pfizer booster jab offers . per cent protection against the virus. Am I eligible for it  As it stands, the booster is only available to the most at risk who have had a second dose at least six months ago.The NHS guidance says it is available to people aged over , those who live or work in care homes, frontline health workers, people who are clinically extremely vulnerable, and carers for, or people who live with, someone who is at risk.Invitations from the NHS to get your jab will be sent to you, as they did the first time around.If you are eligible but have not been contacted, you can use this portal to book on the NHS website. Due to the enforced six month delay post second jab, many have been left waiting for their booster, but there are reports this might be slashed to five months which would instantly make millions more eligible. How many people have had boosters - and how many have not attended In his press conference on Wednesday, Health Secretary Sajid Javid implied many people were not getting their booster jabs despite being eligible.As of October , .million people had received their booster jabs according to the NHS website. However, according to calculations from John Roberts, from the Covid- Actuaries Response Group, there are . million people now eligible for a booster. This means there are .million people who are eligible for the booster but have not taken it yet.  It is this figure which is worrying many, ahead of what will likely be a tough winter and contrasted to what was previously a very successful vaccine rollout. Whataposs causing all the confusion  As stated, Britain began the booster jabs later than most countries and was always playing catch up. Added to that, complications of trying to reach very specic groups for their boosters alongside jabbing school children in their schools complicates roll out. Large parts of the public seem to have become complacent about covid and are less urgent in arranging and going for booster jabs than they initially were. None of this has been helped by poor communication from the government who have not pushed the booster programme as hard as they did the first vaccination programme.  That is due to change from this week, with the government rolling out a TV ad to convince people to get the jab as well as targeted ads online. The confusion was only worsened when health minister Edward Argar told Sky News that anyone who had had their second jab “six months and one week ago” should go onto the NHS website or call  to book their booster, eventhey have not had an invite. However, the website stresses only eligible people who have been contacted by the NHS can book.  Where are Boris Johnson and the vaccine minister Despite being, rightly, very vocal on the initial rollout and its success, Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the government have not had much to say about the boosters until this week’s press conference, which was the first press conference in over a month.There have been efforts during the last few weeks, to move back to a ‘politics as usual’ and escape the pandemic.Boris has been on holiday in Marbella, where he was photographed painting and relaxing, despite the growing crisis at home.Nadhim Zahawi was widely seen to have led the initial jab effort as vaccine minister well during the earlier months of the pandemic. However, he has since been promoted to Education Secretary and in his stead Maggie Throup was promoted to the role of vaccines boss. Despite having been in the job for over a month now, Throup has not made a single national appearance despite issues around the booster rollout. title: who eligible covid 19 booster
story: Who is eligible for Covid- booster jab - and how you can book an appointmentIn September, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationrecommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical conditionEstimates reported where suggest that  million people would be ready for a third vaccine by mid-December Image: PAByAbigail OLearyReporter:,  Oct  recommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical condition" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _covid-booster.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" recommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical condition" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _covid-booster.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" recommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical condition" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _covid-booster.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsCovid booster jabs could be offered to nine millions Brits a month earlier than planned as the government launched a aposmedia blitzapos encouraging uptake of the jab. In September, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationrecommended that everyone over  be offered a third dose of a Covid vaccine, as well as medical staff and younger adults with medical conditions.Only those who had had their second jab six months or more ago would be invited for a booster. Estimates reported where suggest that  million people would be ready for a third vaccine by mid-December. But at the current rate of roll-out, all the most at risk will not be jabbed again until the end of January. The push to encourage vaccine take-up comes as the daily number of cases reported in the UK surpassed , for the first time since mid-July. However, millions remain unsure of their eligibility for the jab and how to go about getting it. Here are some questions about boosters answered. Why is a booster needed  A booster jab will top up the immunity of those already fully inoculated against the virus. The NHS said a booster jab will help improve the protection you have from your first two doses of the vaccine, helping to give you longer-term protection against getting seriously ill from Covid-.  Does a booster make a big dference  A booster shot of the vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech has a dramatic effect, the firms claimed after a trial. A booster dose given to patients who had the initial two jabs showed a relative vaccine efficacy of .% when compared with those who did not receive a booster. Pfizer said that during the study period, there were five cases of Covid- in the booster group, and  cases in the non-boosted group.  Who is eligible  Those eligible for boosters include anyone aged  and over, people living and working in care homes for the elderly, and frontline health and social care workers. All those who are clinically extremely vulnerable and anyone aged  to  in an at-risk group for Covidwill also be eligible for a jab. Adults who share a household with vulnerable people will also be offered the booster. At what point do people receive a booster Booster doses can only be offered to people who are at least six months on from receiving their second dose of coronavirus vaccine. But there is talk of that changing  Yes. The interval between a second dose of Covid- vaccine and a booster could be cut from six months to five under plans reportedly being discussed by ministers and experts. The Government said the time interval between doses was a matter for the experts on the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation . What jab will be given as a booster  The JCVI expressed a preference for people to get the Pfizer jab as a third dose, regardless of which jab they were initially given. But it said that half doses of the Moderna jab could be used as an alternative. Some people may be offered a booster dose of the Oxford AstraZeneca vaccinethey cannot have the Pfizer BioNTech or Moderna vaccine, the NHS said. How do I book a booster appointment  The NHS says most people will be invited to book an appointment at a larger vaccination centre, pharmacy, or local NHS service such as a GP surgery. People who have not received an invitation within one week of the six month milestone can book an appointment online without an invitation.  Can I get the flu jab at the same time as the booster  Yes. The NHS says that most people who can get a Covid- booster vaccine are also eligible for the annual flu vaccine and it is safe to have them at the same time. The UKaposs flu season usually begins in September and ends in March but the NHS usually starts to feel the pressure in January. However Dr McCauley - a prominent flu scientist based at Londonaposs Francis Crick Institute - says Brits should prepare for an earlier surge in cases due to a rise in infections overseas. story: Amanda Knox gives birth to baby girl after sharing details of tragic miscarriageAmanda Knox, , and husband Christopher Robinson welcomed a girl named Eureka - she is the first child of Knox, who was acquitted in the murder of former roommate Meredith Kercher by the Italian supreme court in Amanda Knox has announced shes given birth to a baby girl Image: NBCU Photo Bank via Getty ImagesByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsAmanda Knox has given birth to a baby girl, she said on Friday.The little girl is named Eureka and the first child of Knox, who was acquitted in the murder of former roommate Meredith Kercher by the Italian supreme court in .The news comes shortly after Knox revealed that she and her husband Christopher Robinson has previously suffered a miscarriage. Knox told listeners of Labyrinths about the horror of inducing a painful birth after her babyaposs death. In July, he tweeted: Season  of Labyrinths premieres today with episode  of a -part miniseries on infertility. In today’s episode, I bare my soul about my recent miscarriage. Knox, who married Christopher in , added: We thought it was a straight line from unprotected sex to baby. It was abdominal pain like I have not experienced before. I was shaking. In an audio clip from the most recent episode, she talks about taking a pregnancy test, hoping for three bars. And then when she saw the positive sign, she could be heard repeatedly shouting yes.
